Broadcast networks (meaning Over-the-air CBS, NBC, ABC, FOX, CW, MyTV, affiliates) can allow swear words and brief nudity but they have to put up the "The following program contains scenes of nudity and course language, viewer's discretion is advised" announcement before its starts up again after a commercial break. The main reason is Christian-Right-wing-conservative associations pushing to have tv PG-13'ized for their children. 
 
 Once again broadcast affiliates have more specific rules bounding this. BUT on cable/satellite specialty channels they don't have to censor anything. But stupidly because of these safe-kids associations channels like Comedy Central bleep words during the Daily Show and Colbert Report and South Park, and such when they are not required too.
 
 These groups would boycott them and petition them with media if they didn't. 
 
 Anyways American's don't have it nearly as bad as Canada. We have a commission called the CRTC that requires 50% of our 6-12 lineup on Canadian broadcast networks be original Canadian content. 
 
 We also are missing so many great American channels for 2 reasons:
 
 1) They have not been approved yet (takes them forever) such channels as Oxegen and TNT and HDnet, etc.
 
 2) We are stuck with Canadian versions that don't contain nearly the good amount of content as the American originals.
 
 We don't even get HBO or Showcase as we have to have a Canadian version called Movie Central that misses alot of good HBO series or is late getting them up here.
 
 Thats my 2 cents.

Who the heck is Kwim?
 
 Anyway, am I the only parent who doesn't find censorship very effective parenting? I have rarely censored. My son is 12 - his father and I answer his sex questions as they come up. I don't keep porn around because I think its trash, but if sex comes up in another program we are watching I don't feel a need to sheild him from it. Same goes for violence. I don't watch stuff where the sole entertainment value is blowing things up (i.e., Rambo), but I don't shut down on all violence. We talk about these things, I answer his questions, and he knows the difference between fantasy and reality. As far as I see it, my son lives in this world and needs to understand the realities of this world - and the reality is that we sexual, we cuss, and we are violent. Of course each parent needs to raise their child as they see fit and within the moral compass they feel is right - - but personally I feel censorship should be used sparingly. The world will not be what we wish it to be, it will always be what it is.
